review_blob: Some serious toffee and dried fruit tastes in this flat Czech beer. Really glad I was gifted it although Id kept it refrigerated for nearly a year before I found out it was just over 10% rather than 24%. Take it between meals to fend off hunger for tea for another hour or two. I see others are describing it as over-the-top on here, but its acceptable as any strong beer can be for me. And by that I mean its brilliant.

Not bad for one of the most generic real ales going. The sort of one you see going in a franchise pub or a huge mock Tudor pub off a slip road as a "hey look, we sell real ale now TAKE IT" option while children scrike and run around the place and the polite but thick waitress tells you the chefs gone off even though its not yet 2pm. All I can currently think of it is a template of an IPA, which isnt a bad thing. No, the reason Greene King IPA is a bad thing is that they close down smaller breweries. Also, I kept this in a can once for over a year before resorting to it, and the result was a completely ridiculously festy expired brew, which I used to scare my mates with before pouring down the sink.

Traditional deliciousness from the midlands brewery you cant avoid down there. A high-ABV brew that still demands bit gulps, where you get plums, raisins, muck and general sweetness. Nice to see one of the big chains keeping summat so unique and worthy of being an end-of-week treat rather than a passable session ale. The only beer to date I have taken into a bath with me.

The ever-modified Anchor Christmas special came to me this year with a huge price tag, and was kept in far too cold a fridge. Not to be sampled below 9C as a rough estimate! The Brudenell didnt give me such luck this time and the complexity was therefore lost quite a bit, but hey you got licorice, pines and mulled wine spice blends. It just quickly left the palette at that temperature. Have geared the rating conservatively towards that potential, like the humourless person I am.
beer_name: Anchor Our Special Ale (2001 and earlier)

review_blob: Yet another big-hop American affair that us British seem to be keen on currently. Little stands out to me from this one though, as one who isnt a huge fan of anything this brash. Took ages to sup. Copper, citrus-y, yeah.

Typical hard-hitting treat from the States. Similar to all those big-hop IPAs Beer-Ritz et al have thrown at me since becoming a student except with this lovely fruitiness on top, like mango, oranges etc . . . enough flavour to eliminate the worst of the acidity you may fear from strong IPAs.
beer_name: Odell Myrcenary Double India Pale Ale

review_blob: Let this into my life last Saturday as a bit of extravagance at a ridiculous price, but what a beer, and how merry it made me. Fizzy at the top with every dark fruit ever grown from a tree packed inside. I shared it with my grandma. She really liked it but said it wasnt as good as Gold Label.

Through word-of-mouth Im told Lambic is sour if you drink it soon after getting it, and sweet if you let it age a little. The only thing Timmermans Strawberry is going to be is sweet, as predicted. It claims to be the best Lambic there is. My experience is limited but when drinks go around claiming to be "the best" they usually mean "the most generic." Neither have I had a great experience with Lambic ales yet anyway, but the flavours here are like a flavoursome, organic fizzy pop with the 4% weight added. I dont get much beer underneath the slightly clingy, slightly over-sweet strawberry flavour that lets you drink in larger gulps, but forces you to rest it a few minutes each time. I think its slightly more obvious in flavour than the Floris beers, and Id personally approach it as a sunny-day fizzy pop than a beer, which doesnt have to be a bad thing as it does have (good) flavour (as well as a bit of additive). It still worked on the night though, a rainy night after a frosty, foggy week. A lasting beverage.

Summat deeply weirds going on here, but my friends and I were more than keen on trying a beer that sounds a bit like "Halifax" and was for sale in Berlin for under the minimum unit price in the UK in ridiculous litre cans at 10%. Imagine blending any old lager in with a bag of picknmix, possibly including the picknmix wrappers, and you have Faxe. Dont expect to be able to open your eyes properly after having it. Drunk from the can as it slowly went to room temperature, at which point it tasted like summat youd find under the settee. Dont know whether Im rating it cruelly or kindly.

My father got me a bottle for my birthday. I dont think hes noticed its for sale in every dull restaurant and he was under the impression it was some luxurious specialty beer. Since I may as well taste these things some day so people dont get upset about me not doing so, as if going for the >99% of beers not ubiquitous in the UK is a transgression but drinking the handful that are made for the L.C.D. to ruin their livers is fun and sociable, I obviously drunk it, and it wasnt even pleasant. Theres nowt to it. Dishwater.

A beloved friend of mine came over from California and I took him to one of my favourite Yorkshire places. He spurned the whisky and the Timothy Taylors for a Stella. I was a bit upset that hed come over here and have something so mass-produced when were back into some golden age for brewing real ales in the UK.

He took the term "real ale" as a "No True Scotsman" fallacy and thought I was putting down his beloved Stella for some artificially valued "realness," so I had to explain to him that it was a lot like craft beer in the USA, independently-brewed to a method I dont quite understand which classifies it as a real ale, like how real cider is basically actually made from fruit rather than radon. Unfortunately I couldnt get through to him, and things were dampened somewhat until we met up with another friend who came up with the perfect analogy for it. It was like your girlfriend telling you she was into philosophy, and you going "Ah! Who do you like then?" and her going "Oh, Kurt Cobain, Jim Morrison."

Stella Artois is to beer what Kurt Cobain is to philosophy.
A real treat and a delight. Just dont expect after drinking it to win an argument with your housemate.
Its big, its red, it might make you good in bed. But Im not sure, because Im more focused on real ales.
Ranks highly on the "beergasm" frontthat first sup of the day. Refreshing citrus it is, and it keeps serving up joy until the pint is done.
This tastes a bit better after finding out its not necessarily a Tesco beerski. Full of burnt bitterness that makes you sup rather than glug.
Good dark beer. Yeasty, malty. Unsure if it deserves the same bottle shape as the Schlenkerla stuff though.

You get all sorts each time you try this, which is confirmed by the other reviews on here. I personally tend to get gum-sucking smacks of citrus out of it, namely grapefruit and lemons, which prohibits you from glugging it down but would you want to anyway?

Hazy but oh well, we love it down Calderdale way. Sediment, yep. Im afraid youre going to have to leave the bottom, which is usually hard for me to take as someone who wants every last drip out of their bottle. One of the more popular LV brews.

Sort of an orange peel with dark chocolate beer, as Im sure youd understand. Youre probably going to see this under the "Suma Penumbra" label, the lovely Elland wholesalers who have adopted this local beer, so look out for that. Its still Little Valley.

One of my favourites just has to be from my local brewery, dunt it. Citrussy with a Germanic kind of flavour (here I say Germanic in the sense languages are Germanic so I can conveniently include the Dutch brewer, van der Spek, in this deScription), and so very quaffable. Ah, home!

I described this as one of the most complete beers Id had to my long-suffering friends when I was supping it one Friday night. So much berry, and the nicest facets of all dark ales, all in its wee bottle.

I think everyone who knows Im into beer has had to put up with me butchering the hard German "ch" in the Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier name. But I cant help it. Im vegetarian and never liked gammon one bit anyway, but this tastes like divine gammon.
I remember this having one of the best finishes of all beers ever. Where did you go, O Ghillie?
I love a bit of Duve. Had one the other night after a tough run and had to stop myself from knocking it back, but usually the alcohol does that for you. Trs tasty.
Often have this along with their Chocolate Stout. Lovely little flavour to it, and its clean and that. Below the banana is a pretty polite regular session beer.

I have this at my local by the bottle and at 2.60 its often hard to tempt myself to try summat new, like the American guest bottles they bring in. Keep it in the bottle so the smell shoots right up your nostrils, which has a dark chocolate brownie calibre of smell, as opposed to the more drier, bitter or coffee-like beans you often get with chocolate beers.
Had this in the bottle and I was dead impressed. Better than the other Deliriums as far as Im concerned, which cost far too much in England. Very quaffable for an 8.5%.
Probably what a muddy bog in the Land of Chocolate would taste like. Supping from all the rainwater between the Malteser-cobbled roads. Noice.
